title: (moved) Camera belt clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/camera-belt-clip Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html

Quick-release belt-grip kind of like a simplified version of the B-Grip. Very useful to have the camera ready without occupying your hands and without having the camera shake around and potentially hit things and get damaged as on a belt. This makes use of the camera_plate from my 3d printed shoulder rig -design. Blog post:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/2011/07/3d-printed-camera-belt-clip.html

Not printed yet.
I plan to do so soon. (As I want to use it.) The idea is to include a pause G-Code and insert the belt before printing the final layers of that large overhang.

title: Printrbot Depth Gauge / Dial Gauge Bed Leveling Mount

description.text: I wanted a "cost effective" digital depth gauge I could use to level my Printrbot bed.  This is a bracket to hold the AccuRemote Depth Gauge.

Print off the following:
-13-165_depth_gauge_mount_male.stl (qtty 1)
-13-165_depth_gauge_mount_female.stl (qtty 1) Hardware needed (either of the below will work):
-#6-32 x 1"L Phillips Pan Head Machine Screw (qtty 3)
or
-#6-32 x 1 1/4"L Phillips Pan Head Machine Screw (qtty 3) Purchase this depth gauge ($20):
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0071SKHAW/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Assembly directions:
Print, and purchase the parts listed above. (The hardware used was extra that came with the Printrbot.) Then thread the screws through the "13-165_depth_gauge_mount_male" part into the "13-165_depth_gauge_mount_female" part (see pictures). The screws should self tap into the plastic. Notes:
-If you have the AccuRemote Depth Gauge take a look at the "AccuRemot Depth Gauge Holder" I published for it (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104060).
-Depending on the extension size used for the depth gauge, the gauge may have to be held "down" due to the spring pressing back "up".

comments.text: able to modify one for printrbot plus V2? Thank.
comments.author: eye2eye

comments.text: brilliant! i usually just super glue a digital caliper to my extruder.. but this is a much more elegant solution.
comments.author: upholstery

comments.text: I'm sure there are variations on how people level the bed, and I am curious to hear what they may be.
comments.author: trth

comments.text:
• I put the depth gauge in the mount and then thread on the extension
  • Put the printer head in the center of the x-axis and home the y-axis
  • Put the mount with gauge on it in one corner and zero
  • Set the mount on the opposing corner (still with the y-axis at the home position)
  • Adjust bed height to zero
  • Move Y-axis to opposing side and again put gauge in each corner and zero
  • Then repeat the process to check bed height

title: raspberry pi 2 no screw snap fit basic case

description.text: Simple case design based on the pi 2 model by lyratron.

Notice to Mariners The inside dimensions on this part need to be correct.
In the design I left a .5mm gap around everything, effectively a millimeter of wiggle room over all. I am finding my one ABS printer/slicer is adding .5 millimeter to the walls and so that removes all the interior wiggle room I built in on purpose. While my one PLA printer nails the spec. So be advised and be sure the pocket size in the bottom part is 57x86, you don't want to force anything here, the SBC should just drop in by placing the edge with the ports in first and letting the other side drop into place.

comments.text: Adding a hi top cap that lets me attach a USB to TTL Serial Cable to the pins then thread it out, back in around the USB and back out for strain relief. It is not really "snap fit and no screw" since I use a "ranger band" (a slice cut from a bicycle inter tube) to hold the cap to the case. But I use that to hold a web cam base to the case as well.

This is a replacement turn signal stalk for a 2006 BMW F650GS.  I made it shorter than the original so it would be less likely to break.  The original reflector and lens from the broken stalk will fit into this model.   It would probably work great printed in TPE so it will flex instead of breaking.
Updated model was added 12/17/17.  The signal part was slightly modified.  I removed the tube that sticks out of the bottom of the post to allow the signal to be printed vertically with the stalk at the bottom.  You will need supports with this but it might print better this way.  Even if you print it lens opening side down it will print better due to not having that tube sticking out.  The tube can be printed separately and inserted into the stalk later.  
As an experiment, I also included a support structure for beneath the signal that may give you a cleaner surface than plain supports.  You can align them yourself if you choose to print it this way.  You would still need some support inside the opening for the top part of the structure. Use your slicer settings for that.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

15% should be plenty

Notes: Print with the lens opening at the bottom. Updated model can be printed with stalk at bottom.

comments.text: It printed pretty well with the lens side down.  I used supports but I think I should have used a better support for the end that is floating out over the bed. Mine came out rough and I had to sand it.  I sanded through too far.  The large head part printed ok without supports.

Completely printable x and y carriages for Solidoodle. Uses LM8UU bearings (x8) with parts clipping on for convenience and easy assembly/disassembly. Glides smoothly without lube and offers adjustment for x-axis belt tension. Original axis travel maintained. More room for extruder fans. Highly recommended to print as a spare at least. Should work for Solidoodle 2 and 3 with longer x-axis smooth rods. UPDATE New designs add cutout for M3 nut to be trapped on all belt attachment, as well as the extruder attachment. Eight needed in total. UPDATE 2 Slight tweaks added for strength. New parts have _2 suffix.

Please refer to attached exploded view with colour coding. Apart from 8x LM8UU linear bearings, most other parts will be recycled. The only thing that may be needed are additional M3 bolts to tension belts. If you replaced other Solidoodle parts like the acrylic extruder, you will likely have these sitting around. If not, they are about 40c each from the hardware store and are very handy to have as spares in various lengths.

  • Print the five parts with a high infill for strength. Depending on your printer calibration, you may want to scale up your flow rate for these parts to ensure a nice tight fit with the bearings.

  • Unscrew and remove the extruder and extruder stepper. Undo the y-axis belts from the original carriage so they are dangling by the pulleys at the front and rear of the machine. Unscrew the two screws for the x-axis endstop (right hand carriage piece). Remove the standard carriage by loosening the all of the hose clamps on the y-axis smooth rods, sliding them back through the rear of the Solidoodle frame and then sliding the original carriage off at the front. Slide two LM8UU bearings (green) per side onto the original y-axis smooth rods, slide the rods forward again, realign them and secure the hose clamps. These rods stay in place like this from now on even if you need to disassemble the entire thing.

  • You will likely need to destroy the original carriage pieces to retrieve the original x-axis 8mm smooth rods as they are glued in. I purchased 280mm long rods from the Solidoodle store (http://store.solidoodle.com/index.php?route=product/product&path=63_66&product_id=74) to avoid this. Rods can be longer if you are happy for them to be poking past the boundaries of the frame.

  • Clip the right carriage piece (purple) to the right hand y-axis smooth rod and bearings (green). Remove the M5 bolt (pink) and belt idler pulley from the right hand side of the original carriage and reattach it to the new right carriage (purple) but upside down (nut underneath instead of on top). Reattach the x-axis endstop (important!) to the right hand carriage just as it was on the original piece.

  • Unscrew the four M3 bolts holding the x-axis stepper motor (black) to the left hand side of the original carriage. Lower the stepper out and then insert it into the new left carriage (cyan). Reattach with the same M3 bolts. The stepper sits lower in the new left carriage piece, so the belt pulley must be removed and turned upside down (grub screw underneath teeth) for the belts to align. Clip the left carriage and stepper assembly onto the left y-axis smooth rod and bearings (green).

  • Take your smooth x-axis rods (either recycled or new) and slide them from the outside through the left carriage (cyan) towards the right carriage (purple). Slide on two LM8UU bearings (green) into the middle of each when they are poking through enough. Continue to slide them towards the right carriage (purple) until they go through the matching holes and sit evenly. Secure them from underneath with M3 screws. There should be four left over from the original carriage assembly that held various bits.

  • Clip the centre_front (yellow) and centre_rear (orange) pieces down onto the x-axis bearings (green). Now rotate them so the centre_top piece (red) can slot down from above, which pushes the front and rear pieces against the bearings, eliminating play in the assembly. Secure the top piece to the front and rear pieces with M3 bolts.

  • Undo the two M3 bolts holding the x-axis belt to the remains of the old carriage. Pierce a small hole through the ends of the belts like how Solidoodle has done with both of the y-axis belts. An M3 bolt will need to go through each of these holes, inserting into the toothed side. Loop the x-axis belt around the left and right pulleys on the new carriage and then start to thread in the M3 bolts to the holes in the centre_top piece (red) to attach and then tension the belt. The x-axis is now complete and should slide nicely from left to right.

  • Attach both of the y-axis belts in the same way. Getting the tension correct on these is tricky. If you are having trouble (carriage hard to move or circles printing as ovals), refer to the following Solidoodle video:
    http://vimeo.com/55031028

  • Reattach the extruder, extruder stepper, etc. There are holes in the centre-top piece (red) that the long M3 screws will go nicely into without needing a nut at the rear. Double check the endstop is back in place and power up the printer.
    • Even without lubing the smooth rods, my printer is gliding nicely and printing nice, round circles. Dimensions in mm. Happy printing!

comments.text: I think these are the same design as the original carriages. I can't speak for everyone, but on my solidoodle the carriages as it arrived had clearly been printed, and it wasn't a very good job. They've held up, but there's gaps between some of the layers, blobs of plastic, uneven layers, etc. Printing a spare set at 0.1mm layer height when everything is tuned up nicely will give some higher quality carriages, then just keep hold of them. If you ever find the part fails, having already printed spares makes things way quicker to fix.

For you beekeeping enthusiasts (like myself), this is a scaled replica of a Langstroth hive.  All parts are separate like the real thing.  This is scaled to be right around 1/5th actual size.  The printed result (without further scaling) is about the size of a computer mouse.  
Many of the STLs were taken from acd's Langstroth model kit.  acd's files were converted to STL and rezised to print without any additional work.  Many new models/parts were added.

Doesn't Matter

No

Notes: All parts can be printed without support. Some parts were printed with a brim for better bed adhesion, but this is optional. The brim is easily removed if used.

At Makerfaire 2015, I printed this in about 10 different materials for people to pick up and try flexing at the Printed Solid table.

Playing with Grasshopper3D, a parametric, algorithmic modeling plugin for Rhino3D.  
Highly parametric grasshopper definition included to play with polygon sides,radius, model size, number of facets, size of the model, attractor strength, etc..  
You'll need to execute planar surface and boolean difference commands after baking the model to Rhino.  
Gross out your friends with nature inspired gross-ness.

https://youtu.be/XVbeiWNqmlc This is made by Kinemaker, an application developed upon OpenSource 3D design language of CraftML (http://craftml.io). You can fork the model and customize at http://craftml.io/Ekgir

Huracán quad racer Spanish for "hurricane"; [uɾaˈkan]) With these 3d printed parts you will be able to upgrade your Vortex to the Huracán. Base carbon plates and electronics from the Vortex will be compatible. You can also build the Huracán using your own FCU and ESC's Will be compatible with Eagle Tree Vector Flight Controller. This model will be called the Super Huracán Parts will be added as they are being developed. Any CAD engineers interested in participating please email [email protected] we will be using Fusion 360 and Sketchup software tools for the project. 4/2/2016 Full carbon clone kit http://www.hobbywow.com/en-newest-vortex-285-ultra-light-carbon-fiber-folding-frame-kit-for-fpv-racing-p241329.htm 3/16/2016 New RCtimer F3 FCU with built in OSD. http://rctimer.com/product-1527.html also matching PDB board. http://rctimer.com/product-1528-index.html 3/6/2016 New alternative FCU are out with built in OSD. Perfect for this build. Also new DYS ECS's that fit in the 12mm tube arms. http://www.emaxmodel.com/fpv-controllers/emax-skyline32-osd-flight-controller-advanced.html FCU http://us.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-DYS-XM-Seris-XML20A-BLHeli-mini-20A-ESC-For-High-KV-Power-Electronic-Speed-Controller-wp-Usa-1025915.html 10/22/2015 Posted photo of Vector version of the Huracan, work in progress 10/20/2015 Flight test https://youtu.be/0ZzILvDtcGA 10/5/2015 Link to Hex self tapping screws for plastic. http://www.mcmaster.com/#96817a310/=z8ofx9 10/5/2015 Big thank you to Dim3nsion for designing and publishing CF boom clamping parts! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1052847 10/4/5 Xeostar has designed new motor mounts click here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1033206 10/4/5 Uploaded full lower plate with Naze 32 mounting and ESC's mounting, compatible with Vortex crash kit. 10/4/2015 Uploaded Poortex front split plate with video TX case. Uploaded Poortex rear plate with XT60 support. These parts are compatible with Vortex crash kit. 10/03/2015 Uploaded Poortex upper split plate. Also uploaded new side plate for Huracan build for Vector flight controller. Poortex upper split plate to be used with Vortex lower carbon plate. http://www.readymaderc.com/store/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=76_310&products_id=4195&zenid=66e8f57f367428cda43a8fb1dd8b1709 10/01/2015 New side plate that can be used also on the Vortex to mount DYS 16 amp and DYS 20 amp after market ESC's Let me know if it can be improved. 10/01/2015 Eagle Tree Vector support coming soon for Super Huracan.

description.text:
The Ultimate Nullifier from Marvel's The Fantastic Four series.
The Ultimate Nullifier is a device of immense power in Marvel Comics. The device made its first appearance in Fantastic Four volume 1, issue #50 (May 1966), in which Johnny Storm retrieves it from the home of Galactus—as directed by Uatu the Watcher—for the Fantastic Four to employ against the threat of Galactus himself. The Nullifier appears as a small, hand-held metallic device with no apparent functionality. When first introduced in 1966 it was described as the only known weapon in the universe capable of inspiring fear in Galactus.

I took an image off of Google, cleaned it up in Photoshop. Made a solid black version, saved it as a PNG. I then took the details, deleted the rest, made them solid black, saved it as another PNG. I ran both images through http://image.online-convert.com/convert-to-svg I think used TinkerCAD https://www.tinkercad.com/ to render both files into 3d. Plain and simple. :)

cymor suggested adding a Tony Buser bobble head on top of the original model. (I blame him.) I got ready to create it and realized I don't know how to make a bobble head. I'll figure that out later. In the mean time here's this. It's the 3d equivalent of photoshopping an image. Let's create new jargon and call it "blendering" (tm).
The license.txt file is for the original body data, and not the rest of it. The head was marked public domain. The little replicator 2 was marked creative commons. If I got the attribution or licensing wrong, please let me know.
I really hope Tony is ok with this. It's meant to be fun. Say the word and I'll take it down.

I haven't tried to print this thing, yet. (busy working on another project) It's going to need raft and supports. I can't imagine it working without them.
It was all loaded into blender. The head was cut off at the neck and latticed into size to fit the neck on the body. There's probably a proper way to do a smooth join but I haven't learned that yet. The body was stood on top of the replicator 2 partly for fun and partly to make it more printable. The jiggly bits were covered with logo pasties cut from the bottom of the head model.

Inspired by the great model from countspatula I decided that the TARDIS needed a pulsing light on top as well as the internal windows. I didn't want to use an arduino or other microprocessor just to achieve this so went old-school with a 555 timer. Most of countspatula's model is retained here with the addition of a new battery holder to take two slide switches from radioshack (275-0007) and a micro breadboard to hold the additional electronics. You can adjust the pulse duration by varying the capacitor and/or resistor.

author: Carrot_or_Stick

description.text:
This is a design I came across some 50 years ago, which I adapted to making wood carvings as gifts. It makes a great keychain item, or fridge magnet, and just as a keepsake. It represents Holy Spirit as a descending dove that landed on Jesus after His water baptism. At the same time, it resembles a tongue of flame that appeared on the 120 followers of Jesus in the upper room. (References in the Bible New Testament.) Also, if you turn it sideways, it resembles an angel fish. I've carved these in many materials including leather. This one I designed in Tinkercad. I've also included a file with a hole to be used as a pendant. I reduced the thickness by half and printed one in red and one in white, then glued them together, just for the colour effect. Enjoy!
Update: I just added a second version with a more defined beak. Either version is great; I'm still learning Tinkercad. :)

title: VR Viewer for Phones and Tablets

description.text:
VR Viewer is a simple, elegant alternative to Google Cardboard and other virtual reality viewers for mobile phones and tablets.
VR Viewer works by blocking the Left side view to the Right eye, and blocking the Right side view to the Left eye.
Slip the phone or tablet into the circle, clipping the device in just like in the original Clip Stand.
The VR Viewer extends in front of the device. Ideally, the band of the VR Viewer will lay half way between the device and the user's eyes. The width of the band should be tuned to fully block half the screen from each eye.
The VR Viewer should be sized to fit device size and viewing distance preferences prior to printing.

AZIBOt is an affordable, Arduino-based open-source, & 3D-printed complete Robot Kit for STEM education in Africa. It’s the ideal tool for introducing students to Robotics, Programming, and Engineering. All parts were designed with 3D printing in mind and only a few require support material. Find more at www.azibot.com. Sponsor an African classroom today by visiting www.azibot.com.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.10 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: We often print at 10% with only a couple of shells. Parts can be printed with more fill. Most parts don't need supports, but a few do. Parts that need supports are the ServoLid, ArmBase, and ArduBoxTop. Jaws should not need supports if printed on the inside of face.
Instructions Full build instructions are available at azibot.com under the "Lessons" tab.
We have now built three full bots!

BOM Printed BOM: You will need to print one of everything except the following: 68 x Links 2 x Guides 2 x Jaws 4 x Wheel2 External BOM: Electronics: 1 x Sonic Range finder from elecfreaks (PN EF03085) 2 x Hunt Sensor from elecfreaks (PN EF04002) 1 x Button from elecfreaks (PN EF04034) 1 x Arduino or Freaduino 1 x battery pack 1 x bluetooth module from elecfreaks (PN EF03079) 2 x Standard size continuous rotation servos 3 x Standard size servos Hardware (McMaster part numbers provided): 16 x Pan Head Phillips Screw Sheet Metal #6 1/2" (90190A148) 68 x 18-8 Stainless Steel Dowel Pin 1/16" by 1.25" (90145A425) 20 x Zink-Plated Steel Pan Head Phillips Machine Screw 4-40 5/8" (90272A112) 31 x Low-Strength Steel Nylon-Insert Locknut 4-40 (90631A005) 11 x Zinc-Plated Steel Pan Head Phillips Machine Screw 4-40 Thread, 1" (90272A115) 4 x Nylon Pan Head Machine ScrewPhillips, 4-40 Thread, 3/4" (93135A278) 4 x Nylon 6/6 Hex Nut 4-40 Thread Size, 17/64" Wide, 3/32" Ht (94812A112) Tools: 1 x Plastic-Handle Screwdriver #1 Phillips drive (5791A38) 1 x Angled Double Open-End Wrench 1/4" (5412A15)

9/29/15: Updated link stl
10/14/15: Full build instructions added to azibot.com
10/30/15:
ArdBoxBottom and ArdBoxTop updated to give relief for USB cable
Arm updated to allow easier insertion of servo.
ButBottom and ButTop updated to fit button better
Chassis updated. It should no longer need supports below rear wheel blocks
GripperBaseLarge updated, should now be able to use screw to hold it to the servo nub.

comments.text: We've been printing them with the flat side down on the bed with no supports or raft.  I'm not sure that we have tried other orientations, but this seems to work well.  Sorry for the delay in response.

comments.text: Thank you!
comments.author: AZIBOt

comments.text: where do we get the code from once we build?
comments.author: excorp

comments.text: We are currently using ArduBlocky to program the robots and there are lessons that teach basic programming on our website.  Otherwise, the robot can be programmed just like any other Arduino.  Hope this helps!
comments.author: excorp

comments.text: Your McMaster-Carr BOM has an incorrect part number.  Your list cites "68 x 18-8 Stainless Steel Dowel Pin 1/16" by 1.25" (90145A424)" but the last digit of your part number is incorrect.  It should be "90145A425".  The part you cited is only 7/8" long.  I think it will still work but I am having to be certain that the pin is inserted deeply enough so that it hits both sides of the center joint.  Note that the correct part comes in bags of 50 so two bags will be needed.
comments.author: jedwards123321

comments.text: You are absolutely correct, I have updated it.  I am very sorry for the error.  Somehow, the first time I ordered, I got the right ones, but the second time, I made this same mistake.  I, too, believe they will work.  Can you use another one to help seat the other one?
comments.author: jedwards123321

comments.text: No worries.  That is a good idea about using a second pin to seat the main pin.  I was going to use an icepick or nail but your idea is better.  :-)
comments.author: AZIBOt

comments.text: On the chassis part, I would ask that you add some additional beveling to the posts that stick out which hold the rear wheels, this to ensure that scaffolding is not needed in that area.  There seems to be plenty of room under these posts to enlarge the bevel or to replace the curved bevel with a simply linear ramp.  The rest of the chassis seems like it should print fine without scaffolding.  Thanks.
comments.author: jedwards123321

comments.text: Thank you for the suggestion.  I will look into this during the next CAD revision.  Originally, it was like this so that the track would not hit the posts, but I may be able to do something with a chamfer that will avoid this interference.
comments.author: jedwards123321

comments.text: Hello Jedwards.  I wanted to let you know that the chassis has been updated.  It should no longer need supports.  Thanks for the suggestion, let me know what you think!
comments.author: AZIBOt

comments.text: I actually printed the original chassis design without supports successful.  The rear wheel posts were a little bit "dirty" on the first and second slices where it tried to extrude in to thin air, but our MakerBot Replicator 2 recovered very well after that and I ended up with a usable part (that only needed a little bit of cleanup).  Still, I'm sure the revised version will print much better.  Thanks!
comments.author: AZIBOt

comments.text:
Question: What fill density % do you recommend?
Also .2 or .3 Layer height?
comments.author: lukedubber

comments.text: We print mostly at 10%.  It seems to work well and is strong enough for general use.
comments.author: lukedubber

comments.text: What layer height do you recommend?
comments.author: AZIBOt

comments.text: We have been printing at 0.2 mm layer height.  Sorry I didn't see that the first time around!
comments.author: lukedubber

comments.text: When importing the link.stl into either cura and slicer, the model is coming out tiny. Is there a scalling factor that needs applying?
comments.author: conoral11

comments.text: Hello conoral11!  Thank you for your interest in AZIBOt.  There should be no scaling involved.  Two things that come to mind though, are that the drawing is in inches.  If the program thinks the measurements are in millimeters, then it will be about 25 times smaller than it actually is.  The other thing is that these parts are pretty small already, only about 1.25 x 0.25 x 0.5 inches (about 30 x 6 x 12 mm).  Hope this helps!
comments.author: conoral11

comments.text: I have the same issue with the scaling of the links.  I scaled it up by 2540% in my slicer and I get the following measurements: 31.75 mm x 6.35 mm x 17.46 mm.  My last measurement seems a little high according to your measurements, but everything scaled together. I Have not attempted to print these yet.
comments.author: AZIBOt

comments.text: That sounds right.  I don't have access to the model right now, but I know for a fact that they are 1.25 inches wide (31.75mm).  Measuring the link I have beside me, they are about a 0.25 inch tall (6.35 mm) and 0.626 inches wide (15.875 mm).  The first two dimensions are the same as the ones you measured.  It is hard to measure the width on assembled tracks, so I would guess the difference is in my measurement.  I would say that scaling by 2540% (changing from mm to inches) is correct.  Sorry if my last measurements were confusing, they were just quick approximations.
comments.author: tuckerkm

comments.text: That is great, thanks for the quick reply.
comments.author: AZIBOt

I made a spool holder for the 1Kg spools I get from ProtoParadigm.  The spool wheels fit inside the spools and I put in bearings so it spins freely.  It's set inside the brackets on a hex bolt (1/2" head).  I built a little stand out of MicroRax 10mm extrusion to hold it.  
The spool wheels are different sized ... one large and one small since each side of the spools are different.

Python library to generate .scad, .stl, or .dxf representation of a qr code given contents for the qr code (URL, email address, etc).
You will need an internet connection since this script uses the google charts API to generate the qr code. Up to date code will be kept here:
https://github.com/brad/qr2cad This was also partially derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10370 TODO:
  • auto encode urls
  • data matrix support
  • Different size options
  • Add option for rounded corners
  • Add option to embed .dxf logo

Just run "python qr2cad.py CONTENT" to create a .scad file. Add "-m" to make a .stl, "-mx" to make a .dxf =========================
[email protected]:~/code/qr2cad$ ./qr2cad.py -h
usage: qr2cad.py [-h] [-x] [-m] [-d MAXDIM] [-z ZHEIGHT] CONTENT Convert qr codes to CAD objects positional arguments:
CONTENT The content you want to create a qr code for. optional arguments:
-h, --help show this help message and exit
-x Defaults to .stl by default, this option changes output to .dxf
-m Outputs qr2cad.scad by default, this options makes the result
into a .dxf or .stl
-d MAXDIM The maximum size in mm to make the x or y dimension.
-z ZHEIGHT The max z-height of the text, defaults to 5. Not relevant for
.dxf files =============================
Examples:
qr2cad.stl
./qr2cad.py -m http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10408

More info on possible qr code contents:
http://code.google.com/p/zxing/wiki/BarcodeContents

There are a lot of good struder designs but I couldn't find anything right for me.
My requirements were:
9mm x 4mm x 4mm thick brushless motor bearing. (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__10201__HK_500GT_Ball_Bearing_9_x_4_x_4mm_Align_part_H60103_.html )
10mm fine pitch bowden clamp for tube for 4mm OD tube. ( http://www.robotdigg.com/product/348/Heavy-duty+push-fit+bowden+connector+4-01 )
Long direct drive 400 step per rev low voltage Nema 17. ( http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/9deg-nema-17-bipolar-stepper-44ncm623ozin-17hm191684s-p-12.html )
side mounted. So I mucked around this last weekend, set it printing late at night and it came out perfectly first time. I love it! :-) Clearances around the 1,75mm filament along the compression path are purposefully minimised to allow for printing Ninjaflex etc. Be sure to insert a stiff spring between the base nipple and the swing arm nipple to force the roller and filament against the pinch roller.This uses a 10mm diameter pinch roller, don't tighten the grub screw until you have some filament fed through the cavities to hold the pinch roller in place. Note that the swing arm has some bridge support built in which will have to be removed before the bearing is inserted. Also wind down your motor current a bit before fitting the linked stepper motor. The extra length gives it great torque.
Use 1 x m3 x 16mmwith an m4 nut for a washer, 3 x m3 x 8mm and 1 x m4 x 10 bolt for the bearing. The spring can be wound from piano wire if you can't find a ready made one. My spring has an outside diameter of 10mm, a wire diameter of 1.24mm and an uncompressed length of about 19mm.

title: Universal Spool Holder (2020  AND 1515 frame mount)

description.text:
This spool holder will attach to a 2020 / 1515 aluminum extrusion frame. It will hold all 1kg (2.2lb) spools of filament. it is even capable of clamping the 1lb Taulman filament spools. Every time my printer retracts I see the spool move. Very free movement and I have had no tangles with the one I have been using. The BOM and Exploded diagram are attached. They can help you assemble the holder.
or you can go to (http://www.instructables.com/id/Frame-Mount-20201515-Universial-Spool-Holder) for build instructions. if you are looking for a shopping list, The attached CSV file has all the stuff you will need. Build video and threaded part by Gregory Nutt
https://youtu.be/JKv47Z0bjf0
Thank Gregory for your hard work fixing this design and improving it! Updated: April 30th 2016
Added like to build instructions
http://www.instructables.com/id/Frame-Mount-20201515-Universial-Spool-Holder Updated : April 20th 2016
Found issues with the M8 screw in the BOM. The part number was incorrect. The screw should be a fully threaded screw. The old part number was not. The problem has been fixed. UPDATED: APRIL 15TH 2016
Neer Compleet redesign.
Improved tolerance stack up issues.
Improved the screw depth for the 2020/1515 frame mount.
Improved the center pice that holds the 8mm bolt.
Improved the outside pice that holds the 8mm nut. UPDATED: APRIL 8TH 2016
Added a fram mount for 80/20's 1515 extrusions. UPDATED: Feb 14 2016
Uploaded new stl files and step files. Changed the orientation of the parts. The will no longer need to be rotated prior to slicing.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mini-Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm Layer Hight

Infill:

40%

comments.text: Why not just print the M8 thread right in the top knob.  It's long enough that it should be quite stable.  I can help you do that if you like.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: Thats a good Idea.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: I've printed 3/8 threads with great success for some cello clamps I designed.  I use OpenSCAD to create the thread and Boolean it to a file in 123D Design.  I have done tapping too, but I worry about damaging the plastic too much.  I also run the tap through the printed thread just to clean it up but it works without it just the same.  Just a little more oomph on the first time through.
comments.author: AdrianW

comments.text: Very cool,
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: I have completed a version of the outer_side_holder that uses the M8 thread with 1.25 thread pitch.  Now, how should I send it to you?
comments.author: AdrianW

comments.text: You could make a variant on thingiverse. Or e-mail [email protected]
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: Another comment I have is that I think that the 5mm bolt would probably be better as a little bigger, maybe M6.  The 5mm seems a little unstable.  Although, that would mean larger bearings too.   Also, a lock nut may be better for attaching to the base.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text:
I would love to see a picture. It would help me understand what you are seeing. Unstable in what way?
The M5 was picked because it fit the common REP-RAP bearings.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: I'm thinking the top part shouldn't have the hex hole all the way through.  How do you expect it to tighten up if the nut can come straight through it?
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: That is how it would look at first glance.  However,  That hole has a slight taper.  It is large enough at the back end to push the nut in.  The front end (pointy end) is very tight.  If you pull the nut out that end you are tightening the holder too much.  A light grip in the spool is all you need.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: Maybe so, all things being equal.  I noticed it tapered.  However, it still came through, even before I put it on the spool!  Doesn't seem like a logical way to design it to me.  Yes I had some other tolerance issues too.  The mounting M5 screw in the BOM was too short.  The M8 is too long unless the nut is almost all the way at the top unless using a bolt that is threaded further down.
comments.author: AdrianW

comments.text: Ok, thanks for the feed back on the part.  I will get you one that has a lip.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: Thanks.  I'm just making comment as a courtesy/feedback.  I'll be modifying the files as needed for my application.  I'll probably add epoxy to hold the nut in the top piece so I don't have to print it again.
comments.author: AdrianW

comments.text: timeshell,
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: I appreciate the consideration but it isn't that big a deal.  I didn't use the part numbers you had listed, but did reference the appearance and the sizes for my selection from the bins at my local hardware store.  At any rate, I'm not going to make a stink over 65 cents.  I apologize if my comments came across as though I was upset because I most certainly am not and was not.  I generally speak up with the hope I can be helpful.
comments.author: AdrianW

comments.text: Ya you did not come across as angry.    It was very helpful.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: I think I have most of the issues you ran into fixed.
comments.author: timeshell

author: mauricioveigazanini

description.text:
Thanks to BluefishNZ and alexnovik, I was able to re-mix the design and made it for a tricopter. The green "dragonfly" is my first attempt with an unmodify spacer...comments welcome. Parts used:
  • Used Cobra 2204 1960kv
  • Used Rotogeek 12A ESC
  • Naze32 FC with cleanflight
  • Lemon DSMX satellite
  • Adjustable voltage regulator (for servo, use between 5-6v)
  • 6045 props
  • 3S 1300/1400mah 40/45C lipo (getting about 8-9 mins.)
  • Emax ES09MD
    • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tD2KYWF6xCA If anyone else is interested, here was my first one (green) with specs below: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:154682 Parts use:
  • DYS 1806 2300KV
  • ZTW 12A Opto ESC
  • KK2 mini
  • Hitec HS-65MG servo
  • Zippy 3S 1000-1300 lipo
  • Gemfan 5040 props (too much vibration with 6030...)
  • FrSky D4R-ii
    • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uqlJm2FxefQ Update: added SkyDro LED bumper and switch to KK2 mini, she flies great on 4S...

comments.text: Nice one! How did you go tuning the tail with KK? I built one almost the same with HS65MG but with naze/cleanflight and I can't get the tail tuned. Was thinking maybe the servo isn't fast enough..
comments.author: Daltron

comments.text: The green one with KK2.1.5 board works great and almost no tail wag. The blue one with the Naze however so far I cannot eliminate it and still tweaking (with little knowledge I have on PID).  The difference are the motor size and larger props and that might be the issue due to vibration.  Once the 4S arrive I'll test it with 5040 and 5045 to confirm.
comments.author: Daltron

comments.text: zmr 250 V2 frame?
comments.author: albo86

comments.text: Sorry for the confusion, this is my second ZMR250 Tricopter so I called it V2. As long as you have a ZMR250 frame it should work...
comments.author: albo86

comments.text: okk.. nice work!!
comments.author: bluem6

comments.text: Thanks.

title: Tetra-octahedral bars & nodes grid structure; chaser and ng nodes v.1

description.text:
This is a design for a small scale structural grid, geometrically composed by octahedra and tetrahedra - that make a rigid structure and pack space -, and physically/materially made out of 3d printed nodes and mdf laser cut bars (not in the first pic which corresponds to a test). There are two different kinds of nodes, that are named "chaser" (the hybrid sphere/polihedron one) and "ng" (the star shaped one), after two friends; the two nodes are "topologically" [?] identical; they can work in the same structure. The design of the nodes depart from 24 mm spheres (the diameter of the star is actually smaller after chopping it on 12 sides to place the cylinders and eliminating the original sphere; the bars have a length of 204 mm, which could be changed, and a cross section of aprox. 3x3 mm [3.2 mm width minus section lost by laser cut) to fit quite tight in the cylinders carved in the nodes (diam. 4.24 mm). The structure can take different shapes and grow in different directions. The one in the pics is made out of one octahedron, four "tetrahedra" and a free triangle; using eleven nodes. I designed it to print it in a makerbot, but am not getting good results yet. The pieces in the pictures are printed in a high end  photo sensible resin 3d printer. It would be nice if someone could check the nodes in a makerbot...
Next step will be to parametrize the nodes so that they can be made larger or smaller with ease and/or change the section of the bars. Ok, this is already uploaded. It's a grasshopper definition [rather old software versions sorry: Rhino v 4.0 SR8 and Grasshopper 0.6.0059). Inside the file there are some explanation of the parametrization. The definition might be a bit clumsy but it is a beginner's effort. I am uploading an explanatory image, too. 
Then i would like to parametrize the grid to be able to fill different volumes and than calculate the number of nodes and bars...
Another direction of development would be toward making larger nodes - for a larger structure - and using the 3d printed pieces for molding/casting in a functional material for this kind of use.
The pieces have been printed and cut at Fab Lab Sevilla, Spain, with the help of Juan Carlos Perez and Jose Buzon. Even if the geometry is rather simple, i have to mention that it is indebted with the workshops in geometrical grids taught by Prof. Antonio Saseta.

Print the nodes with a 3d printer. Cut the bars (barras cutting files) with a laser cutter in dmf of 3mm thickness. 6 nodes with 12 bars will make an octahedron. The bars (dxf) cutting file includes 12 bars. Additional nodes will make tetrahedra on each of the sides. Further octahedra and tetrahedra con be built going on adding bars and nodes in different directions.
Some of the jpgs uploaded explain the geometrical principles, that are easier to see in a drawing that to explain by writing.
Files uploaded include rhino files for the two nodes, stl files for the two nodes, and dxf file for the bars.
//
The grasshopper (parametric) file should allow you to play with the main dimensions of the thing (the node, not the bars).

description.text: I'm working for an exercise start up this summer (which is why my part posting has been non existent for a while) and one of the projects i worked on was a "wear your workout" campaign. The company mainly sells resistance bands, and this belt buckle would allow the user to wear their bands around, and be able to have them on hand at any time. I'm not trying to overtly advertise them, but i thought it was a pretty cool idea, so I made one and printed it up for them. And since the start up works out of an incubator, other people were able to see the coolness of having a 3D printer around! I'm still trying to figure out in this is patentable for the company though(hence the all rights reserved license), so when i figure that out, ill try to make this Public Domain.

Print the buckle, and 2 clips, I used hot glue to combine them, but other glues should work too. 
buy a band from www.rubberbanditz.com (or another circular resistance band provider) and connect it in.

at least 50%

I find myself using bits of failed prints to clear the nozzle end before the first bit of ink is laid down. It's probably a bit of OCD as the idea of a brim or skirt seems to perform the same sort of nozzle clear if you set it up right.
In any case, if you also have a tendency to want to wipe the nozzle, catch extrusions from hitting the model being built (when changing ink), or maybe you want to supersize this for swatting flies, then here's a customizer to let you create something.
The first one I printed was a little small, so I need to set a larger one printing. I'll probably stick with a thickness of 0.5mm though.

For Cateye strada slim
Even a bit more protective than version 1 and 2, and it won't pop out.
The reason why I have made 3 different types is because depending on your handlebar or where you have mounted your computer you may not be able to fit the protector. for example, I can't fit this last version on my bike, as the stem on my bike is too short and the select button will be pressed at all times. This is because the computer needs few more millimetres to fit well, so I have to use versions 1 or 2, which are fine, but they pop out sometimes.

author: Virali

description.text:
Using a solar powered garden light as the starting point, the 3-D case is printed to become the holder and the shadow maker.  By setting the reversed street number ('30' is shown) deep, almost through to the front, the plastic becomes very thin and when the LED is aimed behind the number, it is illuminated.  The LED leads had to be extended to allow the LED to be further away and evenly illuminate the numerals.  The garden light will charge the battery during the day and it will illuminate the street number at night.
The dimensions of the garden light in this case were d=54mm and h=25mm.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: I used 'Polar White' PLA from Robox.

General Advice on how to customise I used openSCAD in a Linux environment and the .scad file is provided. The .stl is also provided if you are lucky enough to find a garden light of the same dimensions. However you will have to be extremely lucky to also have a house number of '30' as well, so best design your own, it is not a hard model. This is an 'idea' contribution. For example it could be adapted easily to a Halloween theme by changing the '30' to a carved pumpkin or a bat shape, just to mention a couple. Using a colour changing LED could also add another dimension. The switches on these lights are really clunky and can be removed with the power permanently hot-wired (the switch is only required to stop the battery being totally discharged in the shop). Enhancements could be using more environmentally stable materials than PLA. Finally the 'front' of the box could have the number embossed and highlighted with paint because as the simple design stands now, the number is invisible during the daytime!!!
Edit: Back of box added 30/9/2015 The back part of the box has been added with a hanger. This could be clipped off and the screws mounted invisibly inside the box if preferred. The LED needs to be a fair way back from the numbers and central to reduce shadows, I may have made the front a bit too thick. The hole through the front was strengthened with a tube support. If you were confident you could use silicon sealer to hold the light in place.

This is the plastic square which is at the end of the bar which connects to the bicycle.  
These 2 parts are initially glued at the end of the bar but mine came lose after a while and I ended up losing one of them. These replacement should work just ad the original. I have printed them out of PLA, we will see how long they last.

Print the 2 parts and glue them together just like the original parts.  
EDIT: The fit on the bicycle side was a bit tight so I made a new set with 16.8 mm for the inner square. The files for this version are the "168" STL files.

The Jew's harp, also known as the jaw harp, mouth harp, Ozark harp, trump, or juice harp, is a lamellophone instrument, which is in the category of plucked idiophones: it consists of a flexible metal or bamboo tongue or reed attached to a frame. The tongue/reed is placed in the performer's mouth and plucked with the finger to produce a note.

Put the sensor in the front piece and glue it in.
Glue the back onto the front.
Glue the arm onto the back.
Bolt the base to the arm.

title: RepRap Simpson (Gada Prize Silver Medalist) DEPRECATED

description.text:
DEPRECATED Simpson is a new grounded delta 3D printer. Build Volume: about 10L
Build Area: about 350mm diameter
Build Height: 190mm
Speed: >200mm/s
Realistic Print Speed: 60mm/s
Cost: $390

DEPRECATED http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Aytfhr2DeeM
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZXEcocEHfRQ
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uug9d01Yyy8 Here is a donation link for those that requested it. Thanks for the support.
https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_donations&business=nicholas%2eseward%40gmail%2ecom&lc=US&item_name=Nicholas%20Seward&currency_code=USD&bn=PP%2dDonationsBF%3abtn_donateCC_LG%2egif%3aNonHosted Follow the assembly pdf. After main assembly, add rubber bands to each arm one at a time until you can push the effector to any location in the print volume and when release the effector will return home. (top dead center) After you have installed the rubber bands run your fishing line. Loop the line back and forth until you have a mechanical advantage that will work for all positions in the build volume. (I will post more details as I build baby Simpson.) I will be adding parametric OpenSCAD files as I get time so there can be many Simpson variants out there. Before First Run:
Load the firmware of your choice. Calibrate all motors so that the change in effective distance of an arm matches what the host software sends. Edit parameters.py to match you machine. Run zero.py to get calibration routine. Use the gauge.stl to measure all the offsets. Place these offsets in the calibration array in parameters.py. Operation:
User whatever slicer program you want. The middle of the bed is 0,0,0. Run the produced gcode through segmitize.py to transform the coordinate system. You may need to do a few dry runs are you modify offset in parameters.py. Disclaimer:
This is all very rough. Let me know if something is wrong. Development Forum:
http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?178,206458,page=1 Enjoy!

title: Tough RasPi Camera mount for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.header: Don't use this, I designed a better one! Click here to look at it!
description.text: I liked Doppledutch's RasPi camera swivel mount, but found that the bed attachment was too tight and the swivel arm was vulnerable to snapping off during assembly. So I mashed the mount arm onto ekidd's generalised webcam mount to create a sturdy press-fit swivel mount for adding Jerware's RasPi camera enclosure to your Printrbot Simple Metal. I've taken the liberty of beefing up the transition between the bed mount and the swivel arm to remove that stress concentration. The Tinkercad source file is here.

• This swivel mount (1x)
  • Three files from Jerware's RPi camera mount project:
    • tiltArm.stl (1x)
    • caseFront.stl (1x)
    • caseBack.stl (1x)
  • You should also print 4x of my ribbon cable clips. Stick one onto the side of this mount and three onto the side of the Simple's bed to route the camera's cable away from the print area.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10

Fit and tolerances This swivel mount should be an easy press-fit onto the Simple Metal's bed. Attaching Jerware's tiltArm object to the top of the swivel arm requires some force, so do it while the part is not attached to your printer. Do remember that PLA can be thermoformed with heat; Just dip the part into boiling water for a few seconds and you will be able to make things fit. Camera improvements You should also add a wide-angle lens to your RasPi camera so that it can capture the entire build plate of the Simple Metal. I bought a "3-in-1 camera lens kit" for mobile phones, which came with a fisheye 180° lens and a combined macro/0.67x wide lens. The 0.67x wide is perfect! I used a needle file to enlarge the existing hole in Jerware's caseFront.stl so that the lens would be a tight press-fit. The RasPi camera should also be focused appropriately.

Why document the design process? Because there's a lot of resources on the net that tell you how to use design software, but fewer that actually show the process of design. Even write-ups for simple objects like this one would help new makers see what goes into a practical design. Remixing There wasn't much involved in this design: I simply grabbed the two parts that I needed, used Hole boxes in Tinkercad to cut off the stuff that I didn't want, and then combined them together. The only thing I did was beef up the part where the arm and the base meet, which I always thought was a weak section of the original. I used a pyramid on its side and again used Hole boxes to cut off the excess.
v1, 29 Sep 2015 Initial release.

text = Wadleigh Library
I needed a tightly closed Pill box that i could travel with. Commercially available items didn't hold the size of the tablests I needed.

I wished a pill box easliy recognisable that I had taken my pills on the right day and right time - morning or afternoon when travelling on business trips. Its easy to forget living in hotels and airports. The base has the day and AM or PM engraved in each cubicle.
Each lid uncovers only one day so its easy to tip out. For the morning pills, I simply cover the PM cubicle with my finger and tip the box upside down. The end lid (for Sunday) swings down 90 degrees and the box is placed on the flat surface. Then you can slide the individual lids to open each day. They will not slide off with the lid in the 90 degree position, so its easy to uncover whichever days you want to access, and see which days you took your medicine. If you fold the end lid back 180 degrees (under the box) it allows all the individual lids to be slid off completely leaving just the base with all cubicles open.
I use this to meter out my pills in the box every saturday morning.
Then I just slide all the lids back on and swing the end lid back into the closed position.

title: Garmin eTrex C/Cx/HCx series GPS Hinged Dashboard Mount

description.text: This hinged dashboard mount is compatible with the Garmin eTrex C/Cx/HCx Vista/Legend series of handheld GPS devices, such as eTrex Vista HCx and eTrex Legend HCx. It is fixed to the dashboard with 3 self-tapping screws. The height of the hinge is parametrized in the SCAD file to allow fitting the mount to the desired opening angle and the space available on the dashboard. STL files of the base plate for hinge heights of 0mm, 5mm and 10mm are provided. An M3x35mm bolt, an M3 nylock screw nut and 4 washers are needed for the axis of the hinge. The baseplate is mounted to the dashboard by means of 3 self-tapping screws. Given that the clip part needs to have some flexibility, ABS is probably the best choice for printing. See also my bike bar mount for the same type of GPS devices and my dashboard mount for the newer Garmin outdoor GPS devices. If you lost the clip that needs to be attached to the eTrex, check out my printable eTrex clip.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: I printed these parts on my DIY box-frame Prusa i3 using a 0.40mm nozzle with 0.25mm layer height and 0.56mm extrusion width.

remixed_from.author: idnarbjm
remixed_from.title: Quanum Trifecta FrSky D4R Antenna V Mount

title: Mount for D4R + Naze32 or CC3D with 36 and 50mm holes

description.text:
I remixed a couple of designs to create a mount where I could put my FrSky D4R-II and my Naze32 (CC3D works too) sandwiched.
It has 50mm and 36mm mounting holes. Use small nylon standoffs on the 36mm holes to attach a Naze32 board or the 50mm holes to use a larger flight controller. It can also be used as an adapter to mount 36mm boards in 50mm mounting holes. Also made a 36mm ONLY version.
This design makes for a very space efficient build and it looks GREAT!
